name: Phosphatidylserine
summary: Phosphatidylserine is a phospholipid that supports cognitive function, memory, stress resilience, and neuronal cell membrane integrity.
description: Phosphatidylserine (PS) is a naturally occurring phospholipid concentrated in brain cell membranes, where it plays a crucial role in cell signaling, neurotransmitter release, and membrane fluidity. Supplementation has been studied for supporting memory, cognitive performance, and stress response, particularly in older adults and individuals with cognitive decline. Some studies suggest it may improve mood and reduce cortisol levels under stress. While PS was originally derived from bovine brain, modern supplements are typically sourced from soy or sunflower lecithin. It remains a popular nootropic and integrative medicine supplement, though evidence varies by indication.

metadata.natural_source: Soy lecithin, sunflower lecithin, bovine cortex (historic source)
metadata.fda_status: Dietary supplement (not FDA-approved for medical indications)

primary_indications: Support for memory and cognitive function
off_label_uses: Potential use in athletic performance under stress
contraindications: Use caution with anticoagulant therapy (possible theoretical bleeding risk)

items: May reduce cortisol levels during stress

sections.text: Phosphatidylserine is a phospholipid component of neuronal membranes, supporting fluidity, receptor activity, and synaptic signaling. It influences acetylcholine and dopamine pathways, enhances neuronal communication, and has been shown to lower cortisol levels during stress. These actions contribute to its role in memory, focus, and stress resilience.

sections.pediatric: Occasionally studied in ADHD (100–200 mg/day); use under clinical supervision only.

sections.text: Cognitive and stress-related effects typically appear after 4–12 weeks of consistent use.

serious: Potential bleeding risk when combined with anticoagulants (rare, theoretical)

other: Discontinue if experiencing insomnia or agitation.
Soy-derived PS may trigger allergic reactions in sensitive individuals.

sections.pediatrics: Investigated in ADHD; otherwise not routinely recommended
sections.geriatrics: Often used in aging populations; generally well tolerated

sections.text: No tapering required; may discontinue without withdrawal.

items: Originally derived from bovine brain, now mostly produced from soy or sunflower lecithin due to safety concerns.
Best studied in age-related cognitive decline and dementia.
Some evidence for use in ADHD and stress reduction, though more research is needed.
